greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Position of first occurrence of n in continued fraction for Pi, or -1 if n never occurs.
comment: All positive integers <= 49003 occur in the first 15000000000 terms of the c.f. (the first that do not are 49004, 50471, 53486, 56315, 58255, ...) - _Eric W. Weisstein_, Jul 27 2013
link: Eric W. Weisstein, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..49003
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Pi Continued Fraction
example: The continued fraction of Pi is [a_0; a_1, a_2, ...] = [3; 7, 15, 1, 292, 1, 1, 1, 2, 1, ...], so
a(1) = 3 (1 first occurs at term a_3);
a(2) = 8 (2 first occurs at term a_8);
a(3) = 0 (3 first occurs at term a_0).
results.author: _Eric W. Weisstein_, Jul 27 2013
ext: "Escape clause" added to definition by _Jianing Song_, Apr 06 2019
